qas.question: What do broken limbs and deep wounds open a door for in a tree?
Decay can spread to all of what part of a tree?
What growth stage of insects bore holes into trees?
What part of a tree often stays impressively sound even when hundreds or thousands of years old?
What evidence do some insect larvae leave in a tree forever?

context: It is remarkable that the <a3_0>inner heartwood<a3_0/> of old trees remains as sound as it usually does, since in many cases it is hundreds, and in a few instances thousands, of years old. Every broken limb or root, or deep wound from fire, insects, or falling timber, may afford an entrance for <a0_0>decay<a0_0/>, which, once started, may penetrate to all parts of <a1_0>the trunk<a1_0/>. The <a2_0>larvae<a2_0/> of many insects bore into the trees and their <a4_0>tunnels<a4_0/> remain indefinitely as sources of weakness. Whatever advantages, however, that sapwood may have in this connection are due solely to its relative age and position.
